data.title: The US has seized over $30 billion in cryptocurrency assets, with the Chen Zhi case accounting for 50%.
data.description: Currently, virtual currencies have already exerted a structural influence on the international financial and monetary systems. However, due to their technological characteristics and regulatory gaps, they have also become a major target for cybercrime and a new arena for financial competition. A report jointly released on February 26, 2026, by the China National Computer Virus Emergency Response Center and other departments, titled "Ready Player One: An In-Depth Analysis of the Global Virtual Currency Asset Harvesting Operation Under US Technological Hegemony" (hereinafter referred to as the "Report"), shows that, according to incomplete statistics, from 2022 to 2025, the United States has confiscated over $30 billion worth of global virtual currency assets through various cases. "In the digital age, virtual assets have become an indispensable financial asset, and also an object of strong regulation and competition among major powers," said a financial researcher. Domestically, virtual currencies do not have the same legal status as legal tender. On February 6, 2026, the People's Bank of China and eight other departments issued the "Notice on Further Preventing and Handling Risks Related to Virtual Currencies" (hereinafter referred to as the "Notice"), which states that virtual currency-related business activities are illegal financial activities. "Currently, countries such as Singapore and the United States have recognized the legality of virtual currencies. Investors who have trade relations with countries that have legalized virtual currencies, or who legally hold foreign exchange, can invest in these countries through legal means. However, it should be noted that even if investment is legal in these countries, the realization and trading of virtual currencies within China are still illegal," Tang Chunlin, a senior lawyer in the financial field, told Caixin. "Therefore, it is clear that if domestic investors invest in virtual currencies and derivatives and violate laws or public order and good morals, the relevant civil legal acts are invalid, and the resulting losses must be borne by the investors themselves," Yang Xiang, a PhD in Law from Tsinghua University and a lawyer at Beijing Hongfan Law Firm, told Caixin. He added that if investors have overseas businesses, they must examine whether the platform possesses compliance licenses in mainstream legal jurisdictions before participating in virtual currencies. In Yang Xiang's view, the biggest legal risk in virtual currencies is not "holding" them, but rather violating money laundering (offshore) or concealing/disguising the proceeds of crime (domestic) during the "deposit and withdrawal" process. Therefore, it is essential to retain original legal source proof for every transaction (such as salary, dividends, or property sales certificates). Under the penetrating supervision of 2026, only assets with a complete chain of evidence are considered "real assets." The report shows that, according to incomplete statistics, from 2022 to 2025, the United States has confiscated over $30 billion worth of virtual currency assets globally through various cases. The Chen Zhi case alone accounted for $15 billion in confiscated assets, representing 50% of the total. The report states, ‚ÄúThe United States‚Äô use of technological hegemony to seize global virtual assets is essentially aimed at maintaining its economic hegemony and the status of the US dollar. On the one hand, it directly plunders global wealth through confiscation and fines to supplement its domestic economic strength; on the other hand, by controlling the regulatory rules and transaction flows of virtual assets, it integrates the digital financial system into the dollar-dominated global financial framework, curbing other countries‚Äô attempts to bypass the dollar through virtual currency assets for settlement.‚Äù Four months ago, in October 2025, the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Eastern District of New York announced criminal charges against Chen Zhi, founder of the Prince Group in Cambodia, on charges including wire fraud and money laundering. Simultaneously, it announced the confiscation of approximately 127,000 Bitcoins under his control, valued at approximately $15 billion at the time, setting a record for the largest virtual asset confiscation in U.S. judicial history. In November 2025, the National Computer Virus Emergency Response Center pointed out that a U.S. national-level hacking group had precisely cracked the underlying encryption vulnerability, attacking the LuBian mining pool (belonging to the Prince Group) cold wallet and transferring assets, demonstrating the U.S.'s mature national-level virtual currency asset theft capabilities. This clearly contradicts the U.S. government's claim that "Bitcoin has never been hacked," or its true meaning may be that "Bitcoin has never been hacked by hackers outside the U.S. government." In another case, from 2023 to 2025, the United States pursued both civil and criminal charges against Binance, a renowned international cryptocurrency exchange, and its founder, Changpeng Zhao. The case ultimately ended with Binance paying a $4.35 billion fine (including $2.7 billion in forfeiture of illegal gains, $1.35 billion in civil penalties, and $150 million in personal fines), and Changpeng Zhao signing a plea agreement and being pardoned. The report states that during the investigation, the United States employed comprehensive technical monitoring methods to achieve complete penetration and evidence collection of Binance's operational, user, and transaction data, demonstrating its technological advantages in the field of digital asset platform monitoring. For example, regarding cross-border data theft and internal information acquisition, the United States used hacking techniques to penetrate Binance's internal servers, obtaining core operational data and executive communication records, proving that Binance executives were aware of US regulatory rules but deliberately circumvented compliance requirements. Regarding full-scale monitoring and analysis of transaction data, the report shows that by accessing global blockchain nodes and collaborating with on-chain data analysis companies, the United States has achieved real-time monitoring of Binance's transaction data, accurately locating the trading behavior of US users and the flow of funds to sanctioned regions. Data shows that while US users once accounted for nearly 20% of Binance's user base, only 30%-40% of users completed real-name authentication, which the US used as core evidence of violations. Furthermore, the US technical team conducted penetration tests on Binance's real-name authentication system and anti-money laundering monitoring system, discovering systemic flaws in its compliance mechanisms. Virtual assets are a new type of wealth carrier in the digital age, experiencing rapid development in recent years. According to statistics from CoinGecko (a well-known cryptocurrency tracking and research institution), as of the end of January 2026, the total market capitalization of global virtual currency assets was approximately US$2.73 trillion, of which Bitcoin's total market capitalization reached approximately US$1.57 trillion. Meanwhile, the value of gold reserves held by central banks around the world was approximately $5.83 trillion. This means that the market capitalization of virtual currency assets has reached about 47% of the total market capitalization of global official gold reserves, approaching half, making it a new type of financial asset that cannot be ignored. How can investors hedge against risks? Since 2021, speculative activities related to virtual currencies and RWA (Real-World Asset) tokenization have occurred frequently. These activities have been identified by Chinese financial regulators as significant acts disrupting economic and financial order. On February 6, 2026, the People's Bank of China and other departments clarified the essential nature of virtual currencies, the tokenization of real-world assets, and related business activities: All virtual currency-related business activities conducted within China, including the exchange of legal tender for virtual currencies, the exchange of virtual currencies among themselves, acting as a central counterparty in buying and selling virtual currencies, providing information intermediary and pricing services for virtual currency transactions, token issuance financing, and trading of virtual currency-related financial products, as well as illegal financial activities such as the illegal issuance of token vouchers, unauthorized public issuance of securities, illegal operation of securities and futures businesses, and illegal fundraising, are strictly prohibited and will be resolutely banned according to law. "Conducting real-world asset tokenization activities within China, as well as providing related intermediary and information technology services, which are suspected of involving illegal issuance of tokenized securities, unauthorized public offerings of securities, illegal operation of securities and futures businesses, illegal fundraising, and other illegal financial activities, should be prohibited; except for related business activities conducted based on specific financial infrastructure with the approval of the competent business authorities in accordance with laws and regulations. Foreign entities and individuals are prohibited from illegally providing real-world asset tokenization-related services to domestic entities in any form," the aforementioned "Notice" also stated. However, the "Notice" also opened the floodgates for RWA tokenization activities: Domestic entities directly or indirectly engaging in real-world asset tokenization in the form of foreign debt overseas, or conducting asset securitization or equity-based real-world asset tokenization overseas based on domestic asset ownership, income rights, etc. (hereinafter collectively referred to as domestic equity), should be strictly regulated by the National Development and Reform Commission, the China Securities Regulatory Commission, the State Administration of Foreign Exchange, and other relevant departments according to their respective responsibilities, following the principle of "same business, same risk, same rules." Tang Chunlin reminded that virtual currencies do not have the attributes of legal currency in China, nor are they legal financial investment tools. Furthermore, there is currently no indication that China will loosen regulations in this area or gradually recognize the legality of virtual currencies. Therefore, all virtual currency investment activities conducted within China are illegal investment activities, and investors should be highly vigilant. According to Yang Xiang, many projects claiming to tokenize RWA assets such as real estate and gold are often classified as illegal securities issuance or illegal fundraising in China. Investors participating in such projects are highly susceptible to falling into Ponzi schemes, and the authenticity of the assets is difficult to trace. "Investors with overseas business or compliant overseas status who want to participate in virtual currencies must conduct thorough compliance due diligence. When it comes to cross-border operations or overseas asset allocation, they must examine whether the platform possesses compliant licenses in mainstream jurisdictions, such as a Virtual Asset Service Provider license in Hong Kong or an MPI license (a high-level payment institution license issued by the Monetary Authority of Singapore) in Singapore. At the same time, they should avoid participating in stablecoin transactions pegged to the RMB, which is currently a no-go zone for domestic regulation," Yang Xiang stated.

data.title: Token goes global: Selling Chinese electricity to the world
data.description:
Author:Black LobsterÔΩúDeep Tide TechFlow

In the summer of 1858, a copper-core cable traversed the Atlantic Ocean, connecting London and New York.

The significance of this event was never about the transmission speed, but about the power structure. Whoever laid the undersea cable could profit from the flow of information. The British Empire, relying on this global telegraph network, held the intelligence of its colonies, cotton prices, and war news in its hands.

The empire's strength lay not only in its fleet, but also in that cable.

More than 160 years later, this logic is repeating itself in an unexpected way. In 2026, large-scale Chinese models are quietly devouring the global developer market. Latest data from OpenRouter shows that Chinese models account for 61% of the token consumption of the platform's top ten models, with the top three all originating from China. API requests sent daily by developers in San Francisco, Berlin, and Singapore are traveling across the Pacific Ocean via undersea cables to data centers in China, where computing power is consumed, electricity flows, and results are transmitted back. Electricity never leaves the Chinese power grid, but its value is delivered across borders through tokens. On February 24, 2026, OpenRouter released weekly data: the total token consumption of the platform's top ten models was approximately 8.7 trillion, with Chinese models accounting for 5.3 trillion, or 61%. MiniMax M2.5 debuted at the top with 2.45 trillion tokens, followed by Kimi K2.5 and Zhipu GLM-5. The top three were all from China. This was no accident; a single spark ignited everything. At the beginning of this year, OpenClaw emerged, an open-source tool that truly enabled AI to "do work," capable of directly controlling computers, executing commands, and completing complex workflows in parallel. Within weeks, its GitHub stars surpassed 210,000. John, a finance professional, immediately installed OpenClaw and integrated it with the Anthropic API. He began automatically monitoring stock market information and providing timely trading signals. A few hours later, he stared at his account balance for a few seconds, stunned: tens of dollars gone. This is the new reality brought about by OpenClaw. In the past, chatting with AI involved thousands of tokens per conversation, with negligible costs. After integrating OpenClaw, the AI ‚Äã‚Äãruns a dozen subtasks simultaneously in the background, repeatedly calling the context and iterating in loops. Token consumption is not linear, but exponential. The bills are like a car with its hood open accelerating, the fuel gauge dropping, and it just won't stop. A clever trick quickly circulated within the developer community: using OAuth tokens to directly connect Anthropic or Google subscription accounts to OpenClaw, turning the monthly "unlimited" credits into free fuel for the AI ‚Äã‚ÄãAgent. This was a method adopted by many developers. Official countermeasures followed. On February 19th, Anthropic updated its agreement, explicitly prohibiting the use of Claude subscription credentials for third-party tools like OpenClaw. Access to Claude functionality required using the API billing channel. Google went even further, extensively blocking subscription accounts that accessed Antigravity and Gemini AI Ultra through OpenClaw. "The world has suffered under Qin rule for too long," John immediately embraced domestically developed large-scale models. On OpenRouter, the domestically developed MiniMax M2.5 model scored 80.2% on software engineering tasks, while Claude Opus 4.6 scored 80.8%, a negligible difference. However, the prices were vastly different: the former cost $0.3 per million tokens of input, while the latter cost $5, a difference of approximately 17 times. John switched over, the workflow continued, and the bill shrank by an order of magnitude; this migration is happening simultaneously worldwide. OpenRouter's COO, Chris Clark, put it bluntly: The reason Chinese open-source models have captured a large market share is because they account for an exceptionally high percentage of proxy workflows run by US developers. To understand the essence of token globalization, one must first understand the cost structure of a token. It seems lightweight; one token is roughly equivalent to 0.75 English words, and a typical conversation with AI consumes only a few thousand tokens. But when these tokens are stacked in trillions, the underlying physical reality becomes incredibly heavy. Breaking down the cost of tokens, there are only two core components: computing power and electricity. Computing power is the depreciation and amortization of GPUs. If you buy an Nvidia H100 for about $30,000, its lifespan, calculated over each inference iteration, is the depreciation cost. Electricity is the fuel that keeps data centers running. A GPU at full load consumes about 700 watts of power. Adding the cost of the cooling system, the electricity bill for a large AI data center can easily exceed hundreds of millions of dollars annually. Now, let's map this physical process. An American developer in San Francisco makes an API request. Data travels from California, via a Pacific undersea fiber optic cable, to a data center in China. The GPU clusters begin operating, electricity flows from China's power grid to the chips, inference is completed, and the results are sent back. The entire process may only take a second or two. Electricity never leaves China's power grid, but its value is delivered across borders through tokens. Herein lies a magical aspect unattainable by ordinary trade: tokens have no physical form, do not pass through customs, are not subject to tariffs, and are not even included in any current trade statistics. China exports a large amount of computing power and electricity services, but this is almost invisible in official commodity trade data. Tokens become a derivative of electricity; the export of tokens is essentially the export of electricity. This is also thanks to China's relatively low electricity prices, which are about 40% lower than those in the United States. This is a physical cost difference that competitors can easily replicate. Furthermore, China's large-scale AI models also have algorithmic and "involution" advantages. DeepSeek V3's MoE architecture allows only a subset of parameters to be activated during inference. Independent tests show that its inference cost is about 36 times lower than GPT-4o, and MiniMax M2.5 also has 229 bytes of total parameters but only activates 10 bytes. The top layer is involution, with over a dozen companies like Alibaba, ByteDance, Baidu, Tencent, Lunar Dark Side, Zhipu, and MiniMax trampling each other on the same track. Prices have long since fallen below reasonable profit margins, and operating at a loss to gain market share has become the norm. Looking closer, this is similar to the "Made in China" export strategy, leveraging supply chain advantages and industry involution to drive down token prices. From Bitcoin to Tokens Before tokens, there was another instance of electricity export. Around 2015, power plant managers in Sichuan, Yunnan, and Xinjiang began receiving a group of strange visitors. These people rented abandoned factories, filled them with densely packed machines, and ran them 24/7. The machines produced nothing; they simply kept solving a mathematical problem, and occasionally, from this endless mathematical problem, they would calculate a Bitcoin. This was the first generation of electricity going global: cheap hydropower and wind power, through the hash calculations of mining machines, were converted into globally circulating digital assets, and then converted into US dollars on exchanges. Electricity didn't cross any borders, but the value of electricity, carried by Bitcoin, flowed to the global market. In those years, China's computing power once accounted for more than 70% of the global Bitcoin mining computing power. China's hydropower and coal-fired power, in this roundabout way, participated in a global redistribution of capital. In 2021, all of this came to an abrupt end. Regulatory hammer fell, miners scattered, and computing power migrated to Kazakhstan, Texas, and Canada. But the underlying logic never disappeared; it was just waiting for a new shell. Until ChatGPT emerged, large-scale models emerged, and former Bitcoin mining farms transformed into AI data centers, mining machines became computing GPUs, and the Bitcoins produced became tokens. The only thing that remained unchanged was electricity. Bitcoin's overseas expansion and token's overseas expansion are isomorphic in their underlying logic, but tokens currently have greater commercial value. Mining is purely mathematical computation; the resulting Bitcoin is a financial asset whose value comes from scarcity and market consensus, and has nothing to do with "what was calculated." Computational power itself is not productive; it's more like a byproduct of a trust mechanism. Large-scale model inference is different. GPUs consume electricity but produce real cognitive services: code, analysis, translation, and creativity. The value of a token comes directly from its utility to the user. This is a deeper embedding; once a developer's workflow relies on a particular model, the cost of switching increases over time. Of course, there's another crucial difference: Bitcoin mining was driven out of China, while token globalization was actively chosen by global developers. The Token Wars The submarine cable laid in 1858 represented the British Empire's sovereignty over the information superhighway; whoever owns the infrastructure can define the rules of the game. Token going global is also an undeclared war, fraught with obstacles. Data sovereignty is the first barrier. An API request from an American developer is processed through a Chinese data center, physically passing through China. This isn't a problem for individual developers and small applications, but it's a major weakness in scenarios involving sensitive corporate data, financial information, and government compliance. This is why the Chinese model has the highest penetration rate in development tools and personal applications, but almost no presence in core enterprise systems. The chip ban is the second wall; China's AI development faces export controls on Nvidia's high-end GPUs. The MoE architecture and algorithm optimization can only partially offset this disadvantage; the ceiling remains. However, the current obstacles are just the prologue; a larger battlefield is taking shape. Tokens and AI models have become a new dimension of strategic competition between China and the US, no less significant than the semiconductor and internet competitions of the 20th century, and even closer to an older metaphor: a space race. In 1957, the Soviet Union launched Sputnik 1, shocking the United States and prompting the launch of the Apollo program, which poured resources equivalent to hundreds of billions of dollars today into the space race. The logic of the AI ‚Äã‚Äãrace is strikingly similar, but the intensity will far surpass that of the space race. Space is, after all, a physical space, imperceptible to ordinary people; AI, however, permeates the capillaries of the economy. Behind every line of code, every contract, and every government decision-making system, there may be a large-scale model running for a particular country. Whoever's model becomes the default infrastructure option for global developers gains a structural influence on the global digital economy. This is precisely what makes Washington truly uneasy about the overseas expansion of Chinese tokens. When a developer's codebase, agent workflow, and product logic are all built around an API based on a certain Chinese model, the migration cost will increase exponentially over time. At that point, even if the US legislates restrictions, developers will resist with their feet, just as no programmer can abandon GitHub today. Today's token going global may only be the beginning of this long game. The Chinese model doesn't claim to be disrupting anything; it's simply delivering services to every developer worldwide with an API key at a lower price. This time, the cables are being laid by engineering teams writing code in Hangzhou, Beijing, and Shanghai, and GPU clusters operating day and night in a southern province. This battle for supremacy has no countdown; it takes place 24 hours a day, every day. The unit is tokens, and the battlefield is every developer's terminal.

data.title: Is Circle, whose stock price surged 30% in a single day, quietly becoming the "Visa on the blockchain"?
data.description:
Author: Michael Mach Source: X, @1912212eth

A single quarter's settlement of $11.9 trillion: USDC's size is approaching half of the US GDP.

On February 25th, Circle announced its total revenue and reserve income for fiscal year 2025 at $2.7 billion, a 64% increase. After the announcement, CRCL surged from $61 to $83, marking its largest single-day gain since October 2nd of last year. The market voted with real money, acknowledging the significance of this financial report.

It's worth noting that after reaching a high of $298 following its IPO last June, CRCL's stock price steadily declined, even falling to a historic low of $49.90 on February 5th. This strong rebound is, to some extent, a correction of the market's previously excessive pessimism.

... USDC's circulating supply reached $75.3 billion by the end of 2025, a year-on-year increase of 72%. Let's look at the most crucial metric: USDC's circulating supply reached $75.3 billion by the end of the year, a year-on-year increase of 72%. What does this figure mean? Against the backdrop of a slowdown in the overall stablecoin market, Circle's market share actually expanded by 4.26 percentage points, reaching 28%. The logic behind this shift is simple‚ÄîTether's compliance controversies gave USDC an opportunity, while Circle's long-term investment in regulatory compliance is translating into market share. On-chain USDC trading volume reached $11.9 trillion in Q4, a staggering 247% year-over-year increase. This figure is almost half of the US GDP. While there is significant arbitrage and wash trading involved in on-chain transactions, the 247% growth rate still demonstrates the rapid increase in USDC's penetration as a settlement infrastructure. On the revenue side, total revenue in Q4 reached $770 million, a 77% year-over-year increase, exceeding the average analyst expectation of $748 million from FactSet. Reserve income reached $733 million, a 69% year-over-year increase, contributing the vast majority of revenue. Here's an explanation of the reserve income logic: Circle uses user-deposited USD to purchase low-risk assets such as short-term US Treasury bonds, earning interest rate differentials. The reserve return rate in Q4 was 3.8%, a 68 basis point decrease year-over-year, but the doubling of USDC circulation completely offset the impact of declining interest rates. What truly excited the market was the explosive growth in profits. Adjusted EBITDA reached $167 million, a staggering 412% year-over-year increase, far exceeding analysts' expectations of $130 million. The RLDC profit margin (revenue minus distribution costs) jumped from 30% to 40%, a full 10 percentage points increase. Economies of scale are beginning to emerge; the marginal cost of issuing one more USDC is rapidly decreasing. The financial report reveals several noteworthy business signals. First, there's the progress of the Arc public testnet. Over 100 institutions participated, achieving nearly 100% uptime, 0.5-second transaction finality, and an average of 2.3 million transactions per day. These figures may seem like technical parameters, but they reflect the real demand for on-chain settlement from traditional financial infrastructure. Visa announced that US issuers and acquirers can use USDC to settle with Visa, signifying USDC's penetration into the underlying layers of the traditional payment system. It's also worth mentioning that Circle mentioned in its report plans to launch the Arc mainnet within 2026. Secondly, there's the expansion of the Circle Payment Network (CPN). 55 financial institutions have registered, with an annualized transaction volume of $5.7 billion. This figure is still small, but the direction is crucial‚ÄîCircle is transforming from a simple stablecoin issuer into a payment network operator; the potential of this business model is far greater than simply collecting interest spreads. Regarding the Euro stablecoin EURC, its circulating supply reached ‚Ç¨310 million, a year-on-year increase of 284%. Demand for Euro stablecoins is being activated following the implementation of the MiCA regulatory framework. USYC (tokenized US Treasury bonds) assets reached $1.5 billion, a quarter-on-quarter increase of 111%, indicating increased institutional acceptance of on-chain yield products. The financial report wasn't all good news. For the full year, Circle recorded a net loss of $69.5 million, primarily due to $424 million in equity incentive expenses triggered by its IPO. Excluding these non-cash expenses, the full-year adjusted EBITDA was $582 million, a year-on-year increase of 104%. The reserve return rate has fallen from 4.1% to 3.8%, and this trend is likely to continue. According to the latest data from Polymarket, the probability of the Federal Reserve not cutting interest rates was 97% in March, 86% in April, and 46% in June. If the Federal Reserve chooses to cut rates again in June, Circle's interest rate spread income will inevitably be under pressure. The management's guidance for 2026 also reflects this‚Äîthe revenue margin guidance, excluding distribution costs, is 38%-40%, essentially maintaining the status quo, indicating that the room for profit margin expansion may already be limited.

data.title: Samsung Galaxy S26 Launches Its First ‚ÄúAgentic AI Phone.‚Äù What Does That Mean?
data.description:
Samsung has unveiled the Galaxy S26 lineup, marketing it as the world‚Äôs first ‚Äúagentic AI phone,‚Äù a device designed not just to answer prompts but to execute multi-step actions across apps on a user‚Äôs behalf.

At launch, Samsung is positioning the S26 as a turning point for mobile artificial intelligence ‚Äî moving beyond reactive assistants toward proactive software agents capable of navigating apps, synthesizing information and completing tasks with minimal input.

Gemini-powered agent takes control across apps

At the center of the Galaxy S26 is a new implementation of Google‚Äôs Gemini, designed to function as an operating-level AI agent.

Samsung announced that Galaxy AI will expand with multi-agent support and Perplexity integration on the upcoming S26 series. The update aims to enhance contextual understanding, real-time information retrieval, and smarter on-device AI experiences ahead of Galaxy Unpacked 2026. pic.twitter.com/Fz2XHDl6cU

‚Äî EverImagineTech (@EverImagineTech) February 22, 2026

Rather than waiting for a command and returning a response, Gemini can open apps in background windows, move through interfaces and assemble multi-step workflows while the user continues using the phone.

During the product demonstration, Gemini parsed a busy family group chat discussing pizza orders, identified each person‚Äôs preferences, opened a food delivery app, built the cart and prepared checkout while waiitng for the user to give the final confirmation.

Hence the baseline is that the system does not complete payments without your final confirmation, maintaining a manual approval safeguard. At launch, the feature supports a limited list of major apps including food delivery, ride-hailing and retail platforms, rolling out first in the United States and South Korea as a preview release.

The shift is significant. For more than a decade, mobile AI assistants have largely been query-response tools. Samsung is now attempting to embed autonomous task execution directly into the smartphone operating layer, eliminating the need for repeated taps, app switching or voice commands.

Multi-agent intelligence and AI-embedded hardware

The Galaxy S26 does not rely on a single AI engine. Samsung is layering multiple agents to create what it describes as a collaborative AI stack. Alongside Gemini, the company has integrated Perplexity as a system-level research assistant capable of scanning open browser tabs and recent activity to synthesize answers without manual navigation.

data.title: Vitalik Buterin Sells More ETH Than Initially Planned, Total Sales Hit Nearly $35 Million
data.description:
Vitalik Buterin Navigates Ethereum Through A New Era Of Austerity

The founder of Ethereum is currently reshaping his financial stake in the ecosystem he helped create.

Vitalik Buterin has moved a substantial portion of his personal ETH holdings throughout February 2026, a move that coincides with a broader strategic shift for the Ethereum Foundation.

While the market often reacts with nerves when a founder sells, this particular sequence of transactions appears to be a calculated effort to fund a leaner, more focused future for the network.

By shifting from his original 700,000 ETH down to approximately 224,000 ETH over the years, Buterin is increasingly positioning himself as a participant rather than just a majority holder.

How Much ETH Did Vitalik Buterin Actually Sell

Recent on-chain data from Arkham and Lookonchain reveals that the scale of these sales has slightly exceeded initial expectations.

data.title: What's wrong with Ethereum?
data.description:
Author: Pavel Paramonov & Translation: Plain Language Blockchain

This article is primarily inspired by Vitalik's recent tweets about the current state and changes in the market. While the entire market is declining, it's difficult to pinpoint a specific individual, and I don't intend to do so.

I have worked with many Ethereum teams and invested in multiple protocols built on Ethereum on behalf of venture funds. In general, I used to be a huge fan of Ethereum and EVM-related things.

Unfortunately, I can no longer say the same thing, because I feel that Ethereum doesn't know where it's headed (and many others share this sentiment).

I don't want to discuss ETH's price movements, but I can't ignore the fact that the world's second-largest cryptocurrency has been extremely volatile. Regardless of global market trends, ETH behaves more like a stablecoin that's going off-target. This essay aims to explore what has happened to Ethereum over the past few years and why many are losing hope or have already lost hope. Ethereum didn't lose to Solana or other competitors; it lost to itself. When Ethereum introduced its Rollup-centric roadmap, almost everyone was excited. The promise at the time was that Rollups (and Validiums) would handle scaling, end-user transactions would occur on Rollups, and Ethereum would act as a validation layer‚Äîfocusing on being the L1 for Rollups, rather than a direct-to-user L1. Developing Rollups is much faster and easier than developing L1, so the vision of "thousands upon thousands of Rollups" seems very likely and optimistic. Where did things go wrong? It turns out, everything went wrong. Endless arguments, ideology overriding needs, ongoing infighting within the community, an identity crisis, and abandoning the vision of "centralized aggregation" too late. Everything that could go wrong went wrong. Most of the community initially considered Max Resnick a completely incompetent villain, only to find he was right about almost everything. During his time at Consensys, Max offered numerous suggestions on how Ethereum should move forward, but these were met with criticism and little support. The most foolish peak was when the entire industry started debating whether a certain L2 layer was truly "Ethereum," for example: Viewpoint A: "Base is an extension of Ethereum; we've made huge contributions to the Ethereum ecosystem." Viewpoint B: "Base is not an extension of Ethereum; it's an independent entity." What the hell are we even discussing? How can this kind of dialogue guide Ethereum and its ecosystem towards a better future? Why are people seriously debating what constitutes core Ethereum and what it isn't? Don't we have more important issues to address? This ideological debate isn't a debate at all; it's a confrontation between two small circles trying to prove who's right. We don't need internal friction (PvP); we need external expansion (PvE). We need to understand that this isn't a confrontation between us, but rather a shared understanding of our problems and future. Unfortunately, many people prefer the pursuit of fleeting pleasure to considering that their opinions might be wrong. Technological ideology takes precedence over user needs. Based Rollups, Booster Rollups, Native Rollups, Gigagas Rollups, Keystore Rollups... Which is better, what will the future hold, and how do they connect? "This type is the future," "No, that type is the future." All these discussions... result in Arbitrum and Base continuing to dominate. Technological superiority brings advantages, but these advantages disappear when you compare "apples and pears" or "oranges and tangerines." They are too similar, so similar that users simply don't care. Nobody outside the bubble cares. One more pre-compilation, one less‚Äîyou won't win. "Oh, we are actually 'Ethereum-aligned,' we have an advantage, we are very close to Ethereum, we embody its core values, and users will choose us." I want to ask, which values? And which users will choose you? @0xFacet became the first Rollup to reach Stage 2, they are a model of Ethereum alignment. But where are they? Where are their users, developers, tech KOLs, and those who support the Ethereum ecosystem and alignment? How many of you have heard of Facet? How many applications are available on Facet? I have no problem with Facet personally, I respect its founders. But where are those who keep saying we need more Stage 2 Rollups? I don't know, and you don't know either. Financial incentives are far more powerful than technical incentives. I used to be a fan of Taiko, especially their research on Based Rollups. This model has many advantages: stronger censorship resistance, neutrality, no risk of sequencer downtime, and L1 validators earning more money. Where's the trap? The trap lies in the finances behind the model. You can't force people to give up income for so-called "alignment." Arbitrum promised centralized sequencers, as did Scroll, Linea, zkSync, and Optimism. Where are they? Where are those sequencers? Every Rollup team writes in their documentation: "We currently use centralized sequencers, but have a strong desire for decentralization in the future." Almost no one delivers. Metis delivered, but luckily or unfortunately, people didn't care about Metis. Did I think they over-promised to pander to influential ETH purists (Maxis)? Yes. Did I think they really wanted a decentralized sequencer? Certainly, but it doesn't make business sense. Coinbase (Base) has a legal obligation to make as much money as possible and create value for the company. The same goes for other teams; why would you kill your own revenue stream? It simply doesn't make sense. Only about 5% of Base's revenue flows back to Ethereum. Rollups have never been an extension of Ethereum. Taiko had days when it paid Ethereum more in ordering fees than it collected from user transactions. Clearly, companies like Taiko have many other expenses besides paying Ethereum. Based Rollups or any vision of ‚ÄúEthereum alignment‚Äù are only possible if the team is willing to forgo revenue. I haven't underestimated the importance of decentralization, security, and permissionlessness. But when your sole objective is ‚Äúideological correctness‚Äù rather than ‚Äúuser-centricity,‚Äù it all loses its meaning. Unsurprisingly, this weakness and the promise of ‚ÄúEthereum alignment‚Äù have attracted a large number of grifters. Summarizing the consequences of centralized roadmaps: Eclipse, Movement, Blast, Gasp (Mangata), Mantra: These protocols were never intended for the long-term future. It's easy to hide behind masks of ‚ÄúEthereum alignment,‚Äù making Ethereum better, and introducing SVM to Ethereum. They've all been, to some extent, ‚Äúrugged.‚Äù All Rollups realize their tokens are practically useless because they pay fees with ETH while their tokens have almost no utility. Speculators realize you can create massive hype around a Rollup's central narrative and then cash out by dumping worthless tokens on retail investors. Ethereum has never acknowledged Polygon as a true L2, despite their significant role in securing ETH's value. If you believe Rollups are an extension of Ethereum's "culture," why not acknowledge a project so closely tied to Ethereum's security and usability? Polygon was crucial to Ethereum during the 2021 bull market, contributing significantly to ETH's growth as an asset. But yes, it's not L2 and doesn't deserve the Ethereum community's praise. If Polygon were L1, its valuation would be much higher. Even Paradigm, a top VC that has arguably contributed the most to the Ethereum ecosystem and even developed its own L2 (Ithaca), has shifted its focus to collaborating with Stripe on L1 (Tempo). I believe that when your biggest believer starts building your competitors, something is definitely wrong. The Ethereum Foundation (EF) lacks direction. While Ethereum is technically decentralized, its culture is highly centralized around Vitalik. Ethereum's internal circles are real. As people say, to succeed, all you need to do is get the attention of people around Vitalik and a few influential VCs. I'm not saying you have to agree with everything Vitalik says, but his views essentially define what's good and bad for Ethereum, and you can't compete with that. First, there's ultrasound money. Due to EIP-1559 and the merger, ETH's economic model became deflationary, suggesting it would be a better store of value than Bitcoin. But in 2024, ETH's annual inflation rate turned positive. So the vision of ultrasound money only lasted 3 years? That's not enough to become a store of value. This narrative is dead, and it was never true, because ETH wasn't designed to be a store of value; that's Bitcoin's mission, and you can't compete with that. Then, Ethereum couldn't decide whether its token was a commodity (inapplicable due to dynamic supply changes and staking mechanisms) or more like a tech stock (inapplicable because revenue wasn't sufficient to support a tech company's valuation). There's also the argument that ETH isn't money at all. What's going on? We need to choose a direction. Ethereum can't be multiple things at once‚Äîyou either have a globally unified definition or you'll fall behind. Financial incentives‚Ä¶missing again. I still can't imagine a lead engineer like P√©ter Szil√°gyi receiving only about $100,000 a year for his contributions to Ethereum. This contributor, who has been here from the very beginning and helped Ethereum reach a market capitalization of $450 billion from scratch, received a salary of only 0.0001% of the market capitalization. The most influential and successful protocol in crypto history (second only to Bitcoin) didn't offer any incentives or equity. It's easy to justify hiding behind the creed of decentralization, open source, and permissionless principles: "We're not in it for the money, we're in it for progress." But you have to incentivize even the most loyal warriors, or they'll leave or take on private projects. P√©ter left, Danny Ryan left, and Dankrad Feist went straight to Tempo. Justin Drake and Dankrad accepted advisory positions at EigenLayer in 2024 and received token allocations, resulting in community resentment. These people at EF, earning a "peanut" salary (compared to FAANG companies and AI labs), are being attacked simply for making money and helping a protocol that wants to make Ethereum better (even if it's not Ethereum itself). Are you idiots? Sometimes I feel that if you're an honest, hardworking person on Ethereum, you're deprived of the right to earn money and expected to work like a slave to gain "approval" from Ethereum. EF has been dumping ETH to fund various operations and research. But perhaps they should pay their researchers enough first? Zero tolerance for adaptability. "Day 1. Ethereum will win. The decentralized blockchain with the highest uptime." We hear this every day, just like we hear Ethereum's excuses every day. Yes, Ethereum is expensive and slow. But we have Rollups, use Rollups, Rollups are Ethereum! Yes, ETH prices lag. But Ethereum has the largest developer ecosystem, we have a solid foundation, and demand will follow. Ethereum is the most decentralized! Solana is garbage, they lack client diversity. Ethereum is 100% uptime! Solana is garbage, it has crashed several times. Ethereum's network activity is lower than Solana's. That's because Solana's activity is mostly spam and smurfs. We are an ethical chain! You know, it makes me happy to see people realize their mistakes; it takes courage. But I think it might be too late. Ethereum has once again found the path it has needed to take in the long run, but progress remains slow. EF has indeed seen some changes recently: new leadership, treasury transparency, R&D restructuring, and so on. EF has started hiring young and talented DevRels and marketing talent like Abbas Khan, Binji, and Lou3e. But change must be fast. Ethereum must sprint to prove everyone wrong. Let's see if, after these reforms and changes at EF, we can see Ethereum become an exciting object again, rather than an object of blind, delusional faith and disappointment. Same excuses, same answers, same reactions, year after year. Everything except Ethereum and Rollups is garbage. If Ethereum underperforms on any metric, we say, "This is only day one," we know what we're doing, and there's no better place than Ethereum. Everyone's tired of the community's endless excuses. Ethereum feels like a wealthy old lady who struggles to walk, refuses any innovation, but distributes her wealth to her parasitic descendants. Change. Just hours before I finished writing this, Vitalik tweeted that the centralized roadmap was a failure and they needed to find another path and scale L1. You know, it's gratifying to see people realize their mistakes; it takes courage. But I think it might be too late. Ethereum has once again found the path it needs to take in the long run, but progress remains slow. EF has indeed undergone some changes recently: a new leadership, increased treasury transparency, R&D restructuring, and more. EF has begun hiring young and talented DevRels and marketing professionals like Abbas Khan, Binji, and Lou3e. But change must be swift. Ethereum must sprint ahead to prove everyone wrong. Let's see if, after these reforms and changes at EF, we can see Ethereum once again become an exciting object of study, rather than an object of blind, delusional faith and disappointment.

data.title: Crypto Market Macro Research Report: Crypto Asset Repricing Amid Liquidity Retreat
data.description:
Summary

In the first quarter of 2026, the crypto market experienced a historic deleveraging storm. Bitcoin retreated by more than 40% from its highs, Ethereum fell even more sharply, and altcoins generally halved in value. This round of crashes was not simply caused by cooling market sentiment or regulatory rumors; it was the result of the convergence of three factors tightening liquidity: large-scale unwinding of yen carry trades, the US Treasury's TGA account reconstruction withdrawing funds from the market, and a systemic increase in margin requirements in the derivatives market. These factors, combined with the crypto market's own high leverage structure and valuation bubble, triggered a stampede-like clearing. Looking ahead, the crypto market has moved beyond the "liquidity-driven" extensive growth phase and entered a new normal dominated by macroeconomic factors. Against the backdrop of an unclear Federal Reserve policy path and the contraction of global central bank balance sheets, crypto assets will face continued repricing pressure.

I. Historically High US Stock Valuations: The "Ceiling Effect" of Risk Asset Pricing When analyzing the cryptocurrency market trend, an undeniable macroeconomic backdrop is that US stock valuations are at historically high levels. As the "pricing anchor" for global risk assets, the valuation level of US stocks not only reflects market expectations for US corporate profits but also profoundly influences the valuation ceiling of the cryptocurrency market through asset price comparisons, investor risk appetite, and global capital flows. Multiple indicators confirm the current high valuation of US stocks. The Buffett Indicator shows that the ratio of total stock market capitalization to GDP has climbed to a historically extreme high of 230%, far exceeding the levels before the 2000 dot-com bubble and the 2007 financial crisis. The S&P 500's 12-month forward P/E ratio is 22.0 times, significantly higher than the 30-year historical average of 17.1 times, and close to the 25.2 times during the dot-com bubble. The Shiller cyclically adjusted price-to-earnings ratio is approximately 38, second only to 44 in 2000. The price-to-sales ratio has exceeded 3.0, reaching a historical high. These indicators collectively point to one conclusion: US stocks are significantly overvalued. The high valuation of US stocks is transmitted to the crypto market through various mechanisms. From the perspective of asset valuation effects, when US stock valuations are at historical highs, it means that their expected future returns are declining. Rational investors will reassess the allocation ratio of all risky assets, and crypto assets, as "marginal risk assets" with higher volatility, are often the first to be reduced. From the perspective of Federal Reserve policy constraints, the high valuation of US stocks presents the Fed with a dilemma, limiting its room for easing and potentially leading to a longer period of hawkishness than the market expects, which is depressing for all risk assets. From the perspective of profit-taking, after years of gains, institutional investors are generally overweight in US stocks. When valuations reach extreme levels, they will systematically reduce their risk exposure, typically by selling the most appreciating and liquid assets‚Äîincluding Bitcoin. From a risk sentiment perspective, as a bellwether for global risk assets, the high valuation of US stocks will trigger investor wariness towards all assets with excessive gains and difficult-to-quantify valuations; crypto assets are most vulnerable to being dumped. Looking back at history, any valuation reaching current levels has ultimately ended in a painful mean reversion. The lessons of 1929, 2000, and 2007 are still fresh in our minds. The current uniqueness of US stock valuations lies in the fact that they are a direct product of the longest and largest-scale experiment in loose monetary policy over the past 15 years. When these policies begin to be withdrawn, and valuations are at historical highs, the reversion process may be more severe than before. For the crypto market, this means that even if the fundamentals of the crypto industry itself continue to improve, valuation suppression at the macro level will remain a significant obstacle for the next 1-2 years. Only when US stock valuations return to a reasonable range through time or price adjustments can the crypto market truly begin a new, healthy upward cycle.

II. Yen Carry Trade Unwinding: The "Invisible Pump" of Global Liquidity

The reversal of the Yen Carry Trade was the trigger for this round of crypto market crash and the most crucial macroeconomic driver. For a long time, the Bank of Japan's zero-interest-rate policy has made the yen the currency with the lowest global financing cost. International investors have borrowed yen on a large scale, converted it into US dollars or other high-interest currencies, and invested in high-yield assets globally‚Äîincluding highly volatile cryptocurrencies.

In early 2026, the underlying logic of this arbitrage model began to falter. As inflationary pressures emerged in Japan, market expectations for the Bank of Japan to exit its negative interest rate policy surged. Japanese government bond yields jumped multiple times, with the 10-year yield breaking through 1.2%, reaching a multi-year high. This change directly compressed the interest rate differential between the yen and the dollar: when the cost of borrowing yen rises, while the expected return on dollar assets remains unchanged or even declines, the attractiveness of arbitrage trading decreases dramatically. Even more critically, when the yen begins to appreciate (the USD/JPY exchange rate falls from above 150 to the 140 range), arbitrage traders not only face narrowing interest rate differentials but also incur exchange rate losses. In this situation, the most rational choice is to close out positions: sell previously held overseas assets (including crypto assets such as Bitcoin and Ethereum) and exchange them for yen to repay loans. The crypto market's 24/7 trading and high liquidity make it a prime target for arbitrage traders to sell off their holdings. Data clearly shows that during the few trading days of rapid yen appreciation in mid-February, Bitcoin and yen exchange rates exhibited a high degree of negative correlation, a typical characteristic of arbitrage position closing. It is worth noting that the scale of yen arbitrage trading is estimated at trillions of dollars, and its closing process is often continuous. As long as the Japan-US interest rate differential does not widen again and the yen's appreciation trend does not reverse, this "pump" will continue to draw funds from global risk asset markets. For the crypto market, which relies on incremental funds, this is undoubtedly a devastating blow. III. TGA Account Reconstruction and Treasury Issuance: Liquidity Siphoning by Fiscal Policy If yen carry trade represents international liquidity tightening, then changes in the balance of the US Treasury's General Account (TGA) represent a direct drain on liquidity within the dollar system. The TGA account is essentially the Treasury's "wallet": when the Treasury increases its TGA balance by issuing treasury bonds or collecting taxes, it means funds flow from the commercial banking system into the Treasury's account, leading to a decrease in bank reserves and tightening market liquidity; conversely, when the Treasury spends (such as paying government contracts, social security, etc.), funds flow back into the market, increasing liquidity. From February to March 2026, the market is facing a rapid reconstruction period for the TGA balance. According to the financing plan announced by the US Treasury, the TGA balance target for the end of March is maintained at $850 billion, and it will reach a peak of approximately $1.025 trillion in the April tax season. This means that the Treasury Department will withdraw nearly $200 billion from the financial system in just two months. Meanwhile, to replenish the TGA and finance the fiscal deficit, the Treasury announced a large-scale quarterly refinancing plan in early February, with bond issuance exceeding market expectations. This combination of "bond issuance + increasing the TGA balance" directly led to a continuous decline in bank reserves. For the crypto market, the transmission mechanism is more indirect but equally devastating: reduced bank reserves ‚Üí financial institutions tightening credit ‚Üí decreased financing capacity of hedge funds and market makers ‚Üí forced reduction of risk exposure ‚Üí crypto assets facing selling pressure. Stablecoin issuers' reserve assets are mainly US Treasury bonds; the TGA reconstruction has led to increased volatility in US Treasury yields, indirectly affecting the redemption pressure and liquidity support capacity of stablecoins. Historically, sharp changes in the TGA balance are often highly correlated with the price trends of risky assets. In early 2021, when the TGA balance rapidly declined (due to fiscal spending), Bitcoin experienced a bull market surge; conversely, the TGA rebuilding process in early 2026 corresponded to a sustained decline and eventual collapse in the crypto market. This is not a coincidence, but rather an inevitable reflection of the liquidity cycle.

IV. Margin Increases and Derivatives Deleveraging: Forced Liquidation at the Exchange Level

Besides the tightening of liquidity at the macro level, the fragility of the crypto market's derivatives structure itself was a significant amplifier of the crash. In early February, as the gold and silver markets experienced extreme volatility, the Chicago Mercantile Exchange (CME) repeatedly raised margin requirements for gold and silver futures. Although this measure directly targeted the precious metals market, its chain reaction quickly spread to the crypto market.

Firstly, as the world's most important derivatives exchange, the CME's margin adjustments have a demonstrative effect.

After observing increased market volatility, risk control departments of major cryptocurrency exchanges followed suit by raising margin requirements and lowering leverage limits for perpetual contracts and futures. This effectively forced deleveraging for the cryptocurrency market, which heavily relies on leveraged trading. The forced liquidation of numerous high-leverage positions triggered further price declines, leading to more liquidations and a negative spiral. Secondly, the cryptocurrency market shares a common bullish group with the precious metals market‚Äîmacro hedge funds and trend traders. When these institutions suffer losses in the precious metals market due to margin increases, they often need to sell other assets (including crypto assets) to replenish margin or cover losses. This cross-asset risk liquidation further exacerbates selling pressure in the cryptocurrency market. More importantly, during this crash, the Bitcoin-Ethereum futures premium quickly turned negative (forward discount), and the perpetual contract funding rate remained negative, indicating that the market has shifted from bullish to bearish dominance. When funding rates are negative for an extended period, it means that long positions not only suffer losses from price declines but also have to pay funding fees to short positions. This further weakens the willingness of long positions to hold and prolongs the market's bottom-finding process. Historically, only when funding rates return to neutral or even positive and futures premiums recover can the market truly stabilize. V. The Structure of the Crypto Market: The Dual Vulnerability of High Valuation and Liquidity Dependence Against the backdrop of tightening macro liquidity, the high valuation and high leverage characteristics of the crypto market amplified the severity of the decline. Although crypto assets do not have a traditional price-to-earnings ratio valuation, we can assess their valuation levels through multiple dimensions: First, Bitcoin's market capitalization share. Before this crash, Bitcoin's market capitalization share once fell below 40%, with a large influx of funds into various altcoins and DeFi tokens. This is a typical characteristic of the late bull market‚Äîfunds chasing high-risk, high-return tail assets rather than leading assets. When liquidity reverses, these high-beta assets are often the first to be hit, experiencing declines far exceeding those of Bitcoin. Secondly, there's the change in the total market capitalization of stablecoins. Stablecoins serve as "backup cash" in the crypto market, and changes in their total market capitalization reflect the willingness of off-exchange funds to enter. Data shows that since January 2026, the total market capitalization growth of USDT and USDC has stagnated or even slightly declined, indicating that the speed of new funds entering the market has not kept pace with the market's expansion needs. When the market relies on existing funds and leverage to maintain high levels, any liquidity shock could lead to a collapse. Thirdly, there's the divergence between on-chain activity and price. In the months leading up to the crash, although Bitcoin prices remained high, indicators such as the number of active on-chain addresses and transactions did not reach new highs simultaneously, and even declined. This indicates that the price increase was mainly driven by leveraged trading within exchanges, rather than genuine fundamental improvements or increased adoption. Leveraged-driven rises are often short-lived; once liquidity tightens, prices will quickly revert to their previous levels. The unique characteristic of the crypto market lies in the fact that its participants are far more sensitive to macroeconomic liquidity than other asset classes. This is because the crypto market lacks traditional "endogenous cash flow," and its price is entirely determined by the willingness of marginal buyers to enter the market. When macroeconomic liquidity is abundant, these marginal buyers (mainly retail investors and hedge funds with higher risk appetites) have ample funds, driving up prices; when macroeconomic liquidity tightens, they are also the first to withdraw funds. This round of crash is the most vivid illustration of this mechanism. VI. Market Outlook: Crypto Asset Repricing under the Liquidity Indicator Framework Looking ahead, the trend of the crypto market will no longer be determined by a single factor, but will enter a new stage dominated by macroeconomic factors. Investors need to establish an analytical framework centered on liquidity indicators, focusing on the following variables: First, the Federal Reserve's monetary policy path. Although the market has some concerns about Warsh's hawkish stance after becoming Chairman of the Federal Reserve, it is more important to observe actual economic data. If the job market cools significantly and inflation continues to decline, the Fed's tightening pace may be slower than expected. The CME FedWatch tool shows that market expectations for a rate cut in 2026 have been significantly lowered, but this has already been partially priced in. The key is when the Fed will release a clear signal of a policy shift. Secondly, changes in TGA balance and net liquidity are crucial. Investors should closely monitor the weekly TGA balance data released by the US Treasury, as well as changes in the Fed's balance sheet and ON RRP balance. Net liquidity (Fed Total Assets - TGA - ON RRP) is the most direct indicator of available cash in the market. If net liquidity continues to decline, the crypto market will continue to be under pressure; conversely, if net liquidity bottoms out and rebounds, a phase of rebound may occur. Thirdly, the evolution of yen carry trades is important. The USD/JPY exchange rate and the spread between the US and Japan 2-year government bond yields are two key points to observe. If the yen's appreciation trend stops and the Japan-US interest rate differential stabilizes or even widens, the pressure to unwind arbitrage positions will ease, which is a positive signal for global risk assets, including the crypto market. Conversely, if the yen continues to appreciate, further deleveraging should be anticipated. Finally, there are the structural indicators of the crypto market itself. Whether the total market capitalization of stablecoins has resumed growth, whether Bitcoin's market capitalization share has stabilized, and whether perpetual contract funding rates have turned positive are all important references for judging whether the market has bottomed out. Historically, only when funding rates remain positive, futures premiums recover, and stablecoins flow back into exchanges does it signify a true restoration of market confidence. In terms of specific timing, the second quarter is typically a period of relatively tight liquidity (TGA balances peak during tax season), coupled with the ongoing Fed balance sheet reduction, the crypto market may continue its volatile bottom-seeking trend. A real turnaround may not occur until the second half of the year‚Äîwhen TGA balances begin to decline and the market forms clearer expectations regarding the Fed's policy path.

VII. Conclusion: Saying Goodbye to Extensive Growth and Embracing the New Macroeconomic Normal

The cryptocurrency market crash in the first quarter of 2026 was a systemic deleveraging event driven by macroeconomic liquidity and amplified by the cryptocurrency's own structural issues. It marks the end of the extensive growth phase driven by loose liquidity since 2023, and the cryptocurrency market has officially entered a new macroeconomic normal.

Under this new normal, cryptocurrency assets, like other risky assets, will be profoundly affected by macroeconomic variables such as global central bank balance sheets, fiscal policies, and exchange rate fluctuations. The narratives of "crypto market desensitization to macroeconomics" and "the safe-haven attribute of digital gold" have been disproven in this crash‚Äîwhen a real liquidity crisis arrives, Bitcoin's decline is no less than that of tech stocks, and its correlation with the Nasdaq has risen to a historical high.

For investors, this means a need to establish a more macroeconomic analytical perspective, rather than simply focusing on project fundamentals or technological progress.

Liquidity indicators should be a core basis for investment decisions: pay attention to changes in net liquidity, whether SOFR rates are rising abnormally, whether the US Treasury volatility index MOVE is rising, and whether high-yield credit spreads are widening. These macroeconomic variables will determine the beta direction of the crypto market, while project fundamentals only provide alpha opportunities after the beta is determined. Of course, a crash often breeds new opportunities. When leverage is cleared, speculators leave, and valuations return to rationality, projects with genuine long-term value will present an opportunity to build positions. However, caution is advised until a clear turning point in the macro liquidity environment is observed. For the crypto market, cash is the last scarce commodity, and liquidity is the only truth.

data.title: Romance Turns Into Crypto Trap as US Authorities Seize $61 Million From Fake Dating and Investment Scheme
data.description:
The Costly Illusion Of A Perfect Partner

A massive $61 million in cryptocurrency has been recovered by United States federal agents following a sophisticated pig butchering scam that stripped victims of their life savings.

This enforcement action, led by the U.S. Attorney‚Äôs Office for the Eastern District of North Carolina, targeted a criminal network that thrived on a cruel blend of romantic manipulation and technical deception.

The recovery of such a large sum of Tether (USDT) represents one of the most successful interventions against digital asset fraud to date.

The scheme functioned like a meticulously planned stage play.

Scammers spent months grooming targets through online platforms, posing as either potential romantic partners or elite investment gurus.

Once they gained enough emotional leverage, they nudged their victims toward fraudulent trading websites.

These platforms were designed to look professional, displaying fake portfolios with soaring profits to entice people into depositing more funds.

How Did The Pig Butchering Scam Trap Victims?

The term pig butchering refers to the practice of fattening up a victim with false gains before slaughtering them by stealing their entire investment.

When users eventually tried to pull their money out, the facade broke.

The scammers would suddenly demand taxes or processing fees to release the funds.

Even if these extra payments were made, the criminals simply blocked the accounts and vanished.

In one heartbreaking instance from December 2025, a Bitcoin investor lost his entire retirement fund.

He was manipulated by an online trader who used AI-generated images to create a believable, yet entirely fake, persona.

By the time he realized the platform was a sham, his coins had already been moved into a complex web of digital wallets.

Where Did The Stolen Millions Go?

Tracking the money was a monumental task for Homeland Security Investigations (HSI).

The criminals laundered the proceeds by shuffling the USDT through a dizzying array of wallets to hide its origin.

However, investigators used advanced blockchain analysis to follow the digital breadcrumbs.

They eventually identified several addresses that still held massive balances, allowing them to freeze the assets before they could be cashed out.

Tether, the issuer of the stablecoin, played a critical role in this recovery.

By cooperating with the Department of Justice, the company helped freeze the suspicious addresses and facilitate the transfer of funds back under legal control.

The Department of Justice and HSI accepts Tether for its assistance in moving these assets, the official release stated, highlighting a growing trend of private-public partnerships in the fight against cybercrime.

This $61 million seizure follows another major win in early 2026, where $400 million linked to darknet laundering was intercepted.

While authorities continue to expand their ability to trace illicit movements on the blockchain, they emphasize that prevention is the best defence.

Investors are urged to verify any platform through independent sources before moving digital assets, as the emotional and financial scars left by these partners can be permanent.

data.title: Circle surges 35%, fueling a crypto rebound; Circle becomes a beneficiary of AI panic.
data.description:
Deng Tong, Jinse Finance

>

On Sunday, the cryptocurrency market reacted sharply to the financial market crash triggered by the "Global Smart Crisis of 2028" report. The price of BTC once fell below the $63,000 mark. However, today, the overall cryptocurrency market has rebounded, with the price of BTC even briefly rising above $69,000. As of press time, BTC was trading at $68,368.86, a 24-hour increase of 5.2%. ETH also briefly rose above $2,100, and as of press time, it was trading at $2,064.98, a 24-hour increase of 9.3%.

What drove today's widespread surge in crypto prices? It's Circle! Circle may be one of the biggest beneficiaries of the "Global Smart Crisis of 2028" report. Circle's stock price surged 35.47% today, marking its largest single-day gain ever.

Circle's impressive financial report directly drove a surge in its stock price, ultimately leading to a general rise in the crypto market.

I. Starting with AI Agents and Stablecoins

With the rise of AI, the widespread adoption of AI agents is an inevitable trend and will become the main body of future economic activities. AI agent payments require a programmable, automatically executed, and human-free settlement method.

However, traditional payment systems, such as credit cards and bank transfers, are usually expensive, time-consuming, and require manual operation. They do not support real-time automation or machine-to-machine payments.

To address this issue, Coinbase developed the x402 protocol‚Äîx402 supports features such as automatic payments to creators, pay-per-article, and transactions between AIs. x402 boasts speed, autonomy, and ease of integration. Payments are completed instantly, without the need for credit cards, KYC verification, or third-party payment processors. Developers can embed stablecoin payment functionality into any application, website, or service with just a few lines of code. Undoubtedly, stablecoins can already replace traditional payment systems, meeting the economic activity needs of AI agents and becoming the payment fuel for them. Therefore, Circle, as the world's second-largest stablecoin issuer, will be one of the biggest winners in this AI wave. In January of this year, Circle CEO Jeremy Allaire pointed out that stablecoins will become the foundational payment layer for artificial intelligence. "Billions of AI agents" will soon need a native medium of exchange, and no traditional payment system can meet this demand. "AI agents will continuously engage in economic activities at breakneck speed, often involving transactions amounting to only a fraction of a cent. Using your credit card or making a bank transfer is utterly absurd. In my view, there is currently no other way besides stablecoins." II. Circle's Strategy Last December, Jeremy Allaire explicitly mentioned Circle's vision for the AI ‚Äã‚Äãera: Circle will build an "economic operating system" for the internet and AI age. Circle is best known for its stablecoin USDC, but in itself, it is no longer just a payments company. It aims to become a neutral foundational layer for humans and AI agents to conduct transactions, investments, lending, and coordination globally. At the heart of Circle's strategy is Arc‚Äîan open Layer-1 blockchain designed specifically for payment and financial workflows. Allaire calls it the "economic operating system of the internet." According to Circle, its key features include: Fees are denominated in USD‚Äîallowing developers and businesses to calculate costs using a stable currency, rather than the volatile native token. Fast payment and settlement‚Äîlike a credit card transaction, funds arrive instantly. Privacy features‚Äîsupporting real-world business activities while adhering to regulations. Building on this, Circle has also built its existing infrastructure: APIs, programmable wallets, and tools to embed USDC and smart contracts into any application or workflow. They collectively refer to this technology stack as an "economic operating system." Circle is committed to enabling AI agents to operate economically. Their developer content demonstrates a model where agents collaborate on research tasks and then autonomously pay API or service fees using USDC, leveraging Circle's programmable wallet and blockchain infrastructure for secure settlement. Circle is attempting to redefine how humans and AI systems participate in the global economy‚Äîwho can access it, what rules to follow, and whose infrastructure to use. Perhaps, in this AI revolution, Circle will become the new rule-maker. III. Market Expectations Reflected in Circle's Financial Report Yesterday, Circle released its financial results for the fourth quarter and full year of fiscal year 2025. The following are Circle's financial data: Fourth Quarter Revenue: As of the end of the year, USDC circulation was $75.3 billion, an increase of 72%. USDC on-chain transaction volume in the fourth quarter of 2025 was $11.9 trillion, an increase of 247%. Total revenue and reserve income in the fourth quarter of 2025 was $770 million, an increase of 77%. Net income from continuing operations in the fourth quarter of 2025 was $133 million, an increase of $129 million year-over-year. Adjusted EBITDA for the fourth quarter of 2025 was $167 million, a 412% increase. Full-Year Revenue: Total revenue and reserve income for fiscal year 2025 was $2.7 billion, a 64% increase. Net loss from continuing operations for fiscal year 2025 was $70 million, primarily due to $424 million in equity incentive expenses related to the initial public offering (IPO), compared to a net profit of $157 million from continuing operations in fiscal year 2024. Adjusted EBITDA for fiscal year 2025 was $582 million, a 104% increase. Business Highlights: Arc: The public testnet has been launched, attracting over 100 participants from sectors including banking, capital markets, digital assets, payments, and technology. The testnet is running robustly with near 100% uptime and a transaction confirmation speed of 0.5 seconds. In the 30 days ending February 20, 2026, it averaged 2.3 million transactions per day. Since the testnet launch, total transaction volume has exceeded 166 million. The Arc mainnet is still scheduled to launch this year. Circle Payments Network (CPN) Extension: As of February 20, 2026, 55 financial institutions have registered, and another 74 are undergoing qualification review. As of February 20, 2026, the network's activity continues to grow, with an annualized transaction volume of $5.7 billion in the past 30 days. Digital Asset Growth: As of the end of the year, the circulating supply of EURC was ‚Ç¨310 million, representing a year-on-year increase of 284% and a quarter-on-quarter increase of 44%. As of the end of the year, USYC assets totaled $1.5 billion, a year-on-year decrease of 6% but a quarter-on-quarter increase of 111%, thanks to our relaunch of USYC in early Q3 2025. Continued Growth Momentum: Major enterprises continue to adopt Circle's infrastructure for the secure and compliant use of stablecoins. Visa announced that US card issuers and acquirers can use USDC for full settlement with Visa, enabling continuous settlement outside of traditional banking hours. Intuit launched a multi-year strategic partnership aimed at integrating USDC and Circle's supporting infrastructure into its platform. Circle has partnered with Polymarket, the world's largest prediction market, to promote USDC as a core collateral and settlement asset in its market. The Bermuda government announced plans to become the world's first fully on-chain national economy, powered by Circle's digital asset infrastructure. National Trust Charter: In December, Circle received conditional approval from the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency to establish a National Trust Bank, further strengthening USDC's infrastructure. These performance figures and market results are seen by some analysts as a reflection of investors' expectations for the "AI-driven payment narrative." Conclusion From the panic triggered by the "Global Smart Crisis of 2028" report, which caused a sharp drop in the crypto market, to Circle's stock price soaring due to the AI ‚Äã‚Äãwave, driving a general rise in the crypto market, perhaps beyond the risks, there is more market optimism for the future. Whether looking at Circle's financial reports or the signals released by Circle executives, the trend of stablecoins evolving from a medium of exchange into financial infrastructure is undeniable. Holding USDC, the world's second-largest stablecoin, Circle is already at the forefront of this transformation.
